title: KCl enthalpy - remains after equal masses react

content.description:
K(s) + <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mfrac> <mn>1</mn> <mn>2</mn> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaWaaSaaaeaaca aIXaaabaGaaGOmaaaaaaa@377D@</annotation> </semantics> </math> Cl2(g) → KCl(s)       ΔH° = −437 kJ/molrxn

The elements K and Cl react directly to form the compound KCl according to the equation above. Refer to the information above and the table below to answer the questions that follow.
content.question: What remains in the reaction vessel after equal masses of K(s) and Cl2(g) have reacted until either one or both of the reactants have been completely consumed?

skill.text: 6.D: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using chemical principles or laws, or using mathematical justification.
